summary: On April 17, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California entered a temporary restraining order against Maria Ortega Rangel, a 51-year-old Mexican citizen who was arrested in Arizona for possession of a controlled substance.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on January 23, 2018 in Alameda County District Court, Ms. Rangel was arrested on a warrant for the arrest and detention of her husband, a co-defendant in a drug trafficking scheme, who was also arrested.  The complaint alleges that the arrest was routine and routine, and that Ms.Ortega consented to the entry of the order without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.  In its order, the court held that the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and the pre-judgment provisions of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ("Advisers Act").  The court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and a penny stock bar.   The defendants also agreed to be barred from serving as officers or directors of any federal agency. Â The court's order also prohibits the defendants from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security-related materials, including the receipt of a court order prohibiting them from making or selling any such material in the United States, and prohibits them from serving any officer or director of a public agency.Â   The SEC's order, which was entered on March 5, 2018 and unsealed on April 16, 2018 is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release Release Request No. 17-CV-05390-LHK, No. 206(3) (S.D. Cal. 2010).  The case is being supervised by Sanjay Wadhwa.  This matter was investigated by the Office of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and was supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the FBI, the California Department of Health and Human Services, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Department of Justice, the Internal Revenue Service, the FBI Criminal Investigations, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the San Francisco Office of Inspector General and the California Office of the Attorney General.
